description.narrative: To develop the capacity of, and empower, young women and men to be active citizens participate freely in the democratic process. It aims to facilitate the access of young people to political decision making structures and processes.

title.narrative: Consolidated Report Fiji National Youth Training Final 30102016

description.narrative: To develop the capacity of, and empower, young women and men to be active citizens participating freely in the democratic process.
independent political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

- Geographical coverage of trainings and programmes conducted to promote accountable leadership of youths - Status of national and sub-national youth organizations with established governance structures

comment.narrative: - Governance training and programmes for youth limited to central division and not available to all provinces - lack of established governance structures at national and sub-national levels for youth organisations' engagement in the decision-making processes at both levels

1. Strengthen capacities of youths and youth leaders on key democratic processes. 2. Enhance institutional capacity of youth organisations at national and sub-national levels to support effective participation of young people in the democratic process.

1. Capacity building trainings/workshops completed in four divisions within Fiji for democratic transitions with mechanisms to effectively contribute to key policy frameworks of the Government and National Youth Council of Fiji. 2. NYCF and other youth organisations such as Provincial Youth Forum of Fiji Islands (PYFFI) and Youth Assemblies of Fiji Islands (YAFFI) provided trainings on institutional strengthening and strategic planning for effective engagement with democratic processes. 3. A total of 157 youths directly participated and were trained through a series of national workshops “Building Capacities of Youth to Enable Effective Democratic Participation and Social Cohesion” in four different locations as per table below targeting rural and urban youths in Fiji. The workshop surveys (with 92% participation) indicated that 100% of participants reported achieving their intended learning outcomes under the workshop of which 60% stated they had achieved their learning outcomes that included being trusted leaders, making right (or responsible) decisions, being inculcated with leadership skills and having appropriate skills to solve their issues proactively. In summary, the workshop learning objectives/outcomes were on strengthening of youth knowledge and understanding around decision-making and leadership; raised awareness on key democratic governance principles; discussed on key challenges affecting youth and identifying solutions; and developing capacities and inculcating entrepreneurship skills. 4.A national survey was conducted to gain insights on disabled people. A total of around 500 youths that participated in the National Youth and Sports Conference participated in the survey to provide inputs towards service delivery inputs relative to young people particularly with disabilities. The survey results will be used for 2016 and beyond work planning for NYCF and also for Government.

1. 200 youths with at least 40% females 2. 70% of all new youth officers 3. 200 youths ( with 50% females) 4. Fiji National Youth Report and Pacific Regional youth Report produced and distributed widely 5. At least 5 knowledge products or materials produced

1. 126 youths trained indicated increased level of skills around govenance, leadership and entetreneurship (male:66.6% and female: 33.4%) 2. 14 (20%) new youth administrators were recruited (5 females and 9 males) 3. 273 youths engaged in for livelihood recovery under TC Winston (21% are females) 4. Regional Youth Status report is still progressing and will be published and distributed in 2017 5. 2 knowledge products produced
No target for 2017 as project closed in 2016
No results for 2017 as project closed in 2016

description.narrative: Tonga Governance Strengthening Programme (TGSP)
Elections - elections

- Extent to which capacities of key national governance institutions are improved resulting in increased citizen participation in decision making at national and sub-national levels. - Extent to which capacities of civil society as effective vehicles for effective citizen voices and participation in good governance.

comment.narrative: - Lack of capacities (personal and institutional) in existing national governance institutions and civil society that limit citizen participation and voice in national and sub-national development processes.

ACTIVITY RESULT 1: Legislative Assembly strengthened to effectively carry out its oversight, representative and legislative functions Activity 1.1: Capacity development workshops and resources provided to Members of Parliament Actions: 1.1.1 Two Parliamentary Research Officers provide research and outreach support to MPs and their constituents* 1.1.2 Organize ONE Rules of Procedure training for new MPs and the Speaker, including subject briefings sessions for the Members on Issues such as Poverty, Hardship, Gender Equality, Youth, Environment, Climate Change and Disaster Risk Reduction including issues related to the work of the Standing and Select Committees Activity 1.2: Parliament is better enabled to perform its oversight functions 1.2.1: Parliamentary Committees established, trained and regularly meeting 1.2.1.1 On-going training for committee members and staff on oversight and legal ammendment drafting Activity 1.3: Increased capacity and support resources within Parliamentary Secretariat to support Members of Parliament 1.3.1: Internal organisational reform and reorganisation progressed Actions: 1.3.1.2 Provide improved office space, furniture, and equipment for Secretariat staff with the inclusion of updating software for MPs to achieve a more e-friendly Parliament Activity 1.3.2: Capacity of Secretariat to provide services to Members improved Actions: 1.3.2.1 Ongoing research staff support for information management system for record/ legislation keeping Activity 1.4: Members of the public, including young people and women, understand their roles and the role of their MP’s in a participatory representative democracy 1.4.1: Public outreach and advocacy services Actions: 1.4.1.1 ONE Parliamentary Education Officer provides education and outreach services* 1.4.1.2 Implement communications and outreach strategy for Parliament Television programmes (Panel discussions, DVDs, pre-recorded TV education and schools programme)Radio programmes (su

OUTPUT 1: Strengthened Legislative Assembly effectively carrying out its oversight, representative and legislative functions 1.1.1 Two Parliamentary Research Officers provided research and outreach support to MPs and their constituents: Reported in 2014 quarters and ongoing. These two researchers continued their significant work to assist parliamentary committees in their design and deliberations. (A Civic Education Researcher assigned to CSO-related areas also works with the Parliamentary Research Officers) Accomplishments in Qs 12 included a Code of Conduct for MPs (now in the drafting stage), authoring TORs and Annual Work Plan for parliamentary committees (Public Accounts, Business and Agenda, Social Services, Population and Development, Members' Privileges, Legislation, and Anti-Corruption), drafting of Legislative Assembly annual report 2013-2014, secretarial support to parliamentary committees, briefing to the Speaker on the Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW), assistance to the Legislative Assembly Retirement Fund Board, assistance in the hiring process for the Auditor General, and assistance in preparations for MPs’ research visit to overseas meetings. Throughout, Officers emphasized with Committee Chairs the importance of involving CSOs in the committee process. Officers also responded to numerous formal requests for assistance from MPs and the Secretariat. 1.1.2 Organize ONE Rules of Procedure training for new MPs and the Speaker, including subject briefings sessions for the Members on Issues such as Poverty, Hardship, Gender Equality, Youth, Environment, Climate Change and Disaster Risk Reduction including issues related to the work of the Standing and Select Committees: Two Induction Trainings for MPs were conducted in Qs 12, with all MPs, including the PM, and the Speaker and Clerks, attending the first training involving the former Speaker and a consultant facilitator from Australia. A second Rules of Procedure
* No project activities implemented as the project closed in 2015.
* No project activities implemented as the project closed in 2015.

description.narrative: 1. Number of market vendors trained in, and who apply improved business management practices 2. Number of market vendors trained in, and with increased access to financial services (measured through signup to services) 3. Number of market vendors/ farmers trained in, and engaging in improved agribusiness practices to increase agricultural profitability. 4. Number of market vendors/ farmers trained in, and engaging in improved agricultural practices to increase agricultural productivity.

comment.narrative: 1. No baseline survey on financial literacy and business management skills/ levels of market vendors. 2. Limited capacity to save and access micro finance services (Less than 5% of the market vendors trained had active bank accounts, let alone savings accounts. Nil used insurance products. Nil used their phone or the internet to access their bank accounts.); 3. No baseline survey on agribusiness management skills/ levels of farmer market vendors. 4. No baseline survey on farm productivity of farmer market vendors.

1. 1201 Market Vendors participate in the CMBE training to strengthened financial competencies and record keeping 2. 120 Market Vendors verified as maintaining written records of their business transactions 3. 1201 Market Vendors participate in the CMBE training to increase access to financial and social services 4. 120 Market Vendors verified with new bank accounts after training 5. 434 Farmers participate in the IPI-VF training 6. 43 Farmers verified as maintaining written records of their business transactions/ or using new agricultural methods

1. 60 of the targeted market vendors show improved business management practices 2. 60 of the targeted targeted market vendors accessing financial services , and showing increased income and/or assets over time. 3. 30 of identified vendor-farmers accessing Agricultural Services or Farmer Networks or show continued use of improved business management practices, or demonstrating adoption of the improved, climate and disaster resilient, agricultural methods taught as part of the training. (Note: For the targets, the 3rd target is actually a combination of the 3rd and 4th indicators. We cant split the numbers for purposes of the target because it is very hard to judge which of the indicators the target group will favor as a measure of the success of activity 3. )

description.narrative: 1. Number of market vendors trained in, and who apply improved business management practices 2. Number of market vendors trained in, and with increased access to financial services (measured through signup to services) 3. Number of market vendors/ farmers trained in, and engaging in improved agribusiness practices to increase agricultural profitability. 4. Number of market vendors/ farmers trained in, and engaging in improved agricultural practices to increase agricultural productivity.

comment.narrative: 1. No baseline survey on financial literacy and business management skills/ levels of market vendors. 2. Limited capacity to save and access micro finance services (Less than 5% of the market vendors trained had active bank accounts, let alone savings accounts. Nil used insurance products. Nil used their phone or the internet to access their bank accounts.); 3. No baseline survey on agribusiness management skills/ levels of farmer market vendors. 4. No baseline survey on farm productivity of farmer market vendors.

1. Profiling of farmers in the Honiara and Auki Municple Markets to identify training needs; and 2. Capacity building programme developed for farmers that sell in the Honiara and Auki Municipal markets based on the results of the training needs assessment;

1. Profiling of farmers in the Honiara and Auki Markets completed; and 2. Capacity building training programme for the identified farmers currently ongoing and is expected to be completed in the first half of 2016.

1. 450 Market Vendors participate in the CMBE training to strengthened financial competencies and record keeping 2. 22 Market Vendors verified as maintaining written records of their business transactions 3. 450 Market Vendors participate in the CMBE training to increase access to financial and social services 4. 22 Market Vendors verified with new bank accounts after training 5. 140 Farmers participate in the IPI-VF training 6. 15 Farmers verified as maintaining written records of their business transactions/ or using new agricultural methods

1. 40 of the targeted market vendors show improved business management practices 2. 40 of the targeted targeted market vendors accessing financial services. 3. 70 of identified vendor-farmers accessing Agricultural Services or Farmer Networks or show continued use of improved business management practices, or demonstrating adoption of the improved, climate and disaster resilient, agricultural methods taught as part of the training. (Note: For the targets, the 3rd target is actually a combination of the 3rd and 4th indicators. We cant split the numbers for purposes of the target because it is very hard to judge which of the indicators the target group will favor as a measure of the success of activity 3. )

TC PAM Response and Recovery Programme

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of females benefitting from diversified livelihoods opportunities through UNDP emergency projects
Number of males benefitting from diversified livelihoods opportunities through UNDP emergency projects
Total number of people benefitting from diversified livelihoods opportunities through UNDP emergency projects
Number of new emergency jobs created for women 15+ years of age through UNDP projects in crisis or post-crisis settings
Number of new emergency jobs created for men 15+ years of age through UNDP projects in crisis or post-crisis settings
Total number of new emergency jobs created for adults 15+ years of age through UNDP projects in crisis or post-crisis settings
Supports coordination efforts, needs assessments and initiation of early recovery frameworks, including local coordination in Vanuatu, Tuvalu and Kiribati following Tropical Cyclone PAM
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Coordination support desks set up in a timely manner and operational in Suva, Vanuatu, Tuvalu and Kiribati 2. Damage/Needs assessments undertaken/supported and early recovery frameworks/plans supported 3. Communications products developed

comment.narrative: UN Resident Coordinator Support provided from Suva with minimal support from the UNICEF Led UNJPO offices in Vanuatu and Kiribati and UNDP led UNJPO in Tuvalu. UNDP support from the Fiji MCO assisted by the UNDP Programme analysts based at the UNJPO in Vanuatu and Kiribati and the UNDP CDM in Tuvalu.

1. Support to the UN Resident Coordinator/Humanitarian Coordinator office and UNDP to provide an effective response to early recovery. 2. Development of Post Disaster recovery plans/programme of action for the 3 countries 3. 1 fact sheet and two human interest stories developed

1. Suva: TC Pam desk established to coordinate recovery programme activities within the Fiji MCO Vanuatu: Immediate in country support by the UN Resident Coordinator and UNDP MCO with the establishment of an expanded UNDP presence. Logistical support provided to SURGE consultants to undertake a PDNA and provide technical advice to the Government on the recovery plan. UNDP project proposal developed and USD500K mobilised to implement a debris clearance and livelihoods resilience programme Tuvalu: UNDP presence expanded, UNDP Recovery Adviser, SURGE Debris Management Specialist, Communications Specialist fielded to assist with coordination activities, needs assessments and provide assistance to the Government on the Recovery Plan. 2. Vanuatu Cash for work and Livelihoods Recovery programme formulated and implemented, Tuvalu Recovery Plan produced 3. 3 human interest stories and 2 Fast Facts sheets published, website featured TC Pam stories
Note: Kiribati; Immediate mission fielded to undertake needs assesment but no assistance was requested by Government

description.narrative: VU Livelihoods for Resilience Initiative
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Number of men and women benefitting from temporary cash income - debris clearance 2. Cubic meters of debris collected, classified and recycled 3. No. of alternative livelihood ventures operating sustainably, disaggregated by sex and age 4. No. of partnerships formed to support livelihood ventures 5. Number of community infrastructure rehabilitated

comment.narrative: 1. Unemployed population with lack of funds for basic requirements following devasatation by TC Pam 2. Port Vila and Lenakel municipalities unable to cope with volume of debris to be cleared, lack of equipment and machinery for debris clearance 3.Traditional livelihoods in the Shepherd Is – fisheries, pandanus weaving destroyed by TC Pam, no pandanus plants remaining, fishing boats, freezer/storage equipment damaged 4. No ongoing partnerships in place for income generating activities 5. Community infrastructure used for income generating activities destroyed by TC Pam in the 6 Shepherd Islands

1. 50 men and 50 women participate in CFW Port Vila and 15 men and 15 women participate in CFW in Lenakel 2.1000 cu. Meters debris cleared in Port Vila and 500 cubic meteres cleared in Lenakel. 3. 1700 alternative livelihood ventures operating 4. 3 partnerships formed 5. 6 community infrastructure rehabilitated

1. 129 people provided with emergency employment for an average of 3 weeks each, 56 female and 73 males. 42 are in the youth category; 2. 2465 cubic meters of debris cleared in Port Vila and Lenakel 3. 1735 livelihood ventures operating, 1358 women and 377 men 4. 3 partnerships formed 5. 3 community income generation buildings completed, 2 in progress .

1. rehabilitate/rebuild 1 Community Infrastructure per Island in the Shepherd Islands (6 Islands) 2. 3 Partnerships formed to provide training/livelihood ventures 3. Equipment's supplied for re-establishment of livelihood ventures 4. 1,115 cubic meters of Timber to be supplied to 12 schools on Tanna Island

1. 1 community Infrastructure rehabilitated, 5 newly built community Halls in the Shepherd Islands 2. 3 partnerships formed with ACTIV, Wan Smolbag, Department of Fisheries, 2 Fisheries Training's, 2 sewing Training's, 1 handicraft Training. 3. 6 fishing boats, 4 auto board engines, 14 solar freezers, 4 solar panels, 8 water tanks, Fishing Gears, 40 sewing machines supplied equipment's to re-establish livelihood ventures 4. 7 Schools supplied with Timber for rehabilitation purposes

1. Number of SDG indicators incorporated into the ME Framework of National Development Strategies and Plans 2. Number of SDG knowledge products produced 3. Number of policies reviewed/formulated to accelerate SDG achievement 4. Number of awareness raising activities conducted at national and sub national levels

comment.narrative: 1. Nil SDG indicators incorporated into the ME Framework of National Development Strategies and Plans 2. Nil SDG knowledge products produced 3. Nil policies reviewed/formulated to accelerate SDG achievement 4. Nil awareness raising activities conducted at national and sub national levels

1. At least 30% of SDG targets or indicators (official or tailored) are mainstreamed into the ME framework of the NSDP; 2. At least 1 knowledge product relating to SDGs is produced in 2016 3. No target for 2016 as efforts will be focused on mainstreaming the SDGs into NSDP and Government corporate plans 4. At least 1 awareness raising activity is undertaken either at national or sub-national level (please change campaign to activity in the indicator and baseline)

1. NSDP drafted SDGs have been mainstreamed into ME framework. 2. Development Finance Assessment was completed which looks at sustainable funding sources for implementing the NSDP SDGs 3. Support provided to TC Winston Recovery project on food security re-establishment and recovery of agriculture livelihood on Koro Island. For immediate to medium term, farming tools and Agro inputs were provided to 670 households on the islands and for re-establishing of long-term key livelihood inputs, kava, yasi and pandanus are being sourced. 4. Support also provided to Ministry of Economy through one LOA for consultancy work to be conducted on establishment of a Micro Small and Medium Enterprise (MSME) Central Coordination Agency and also installation of a statistics database
